official-title.#text:
To establish a grant program to ensure that students in
		  high-need schools have equal access to a quality education delivered by an
		  effective, diverse workforce.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Education and the
			 Workforce

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Equal Access to Quality Education Act
			 of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Equal access to
			 quality education grant program

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall make grants on a competitive basis to eligible partnerships in
			 high-need areas to—

text.#text: The

create
			 professional induction programs for the teaching profession; and

provide a stable
			 and collaborative learning environment for educators and students.

The purposes of the grant program
			 established under this section shall be to—

decrease shortages
			 of highly qualified teachers in poor urban and rural areas;

decrease high
			 turnover rates for educators in high-need schools;

increase the number of highly qualified
			 teachers in shortage areas, including special education, bilingual education,
			 and education for English language learners, and in science, mathematics,
			 engineering, and technology;

increase
			 opportunities for enhanced and ongoing professional development that—

improves the
			 academic content knowledge of teachers in the subject areas in which teachers
			 are certified or licensed to teach or in which the teachers are working toward
			 certification or licensure to teach;

promotes strong teaching skills, including
			 instructional strategies that address diverse needs, the use of data to inform
			 instruction, and strategies to improve student achievement; and

provides time for teachers to share their
			 knowledge and innovation; and

provide all educators with the knowledge
			 base and professional skills to meet the needs of diverse learners, including
			 English language learners and students with disabilities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
at such time, in such manner, and containing such
			 information as the
may require.

text.#text:
An eligible
			 partnership that desires to receive a grant under this Act shall submit an
			 application to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: include—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Equal Access to Quality Education Act of 2013/s:2/ss:c/p:1

text.#text:
An
			 application submitted under

a description
			 of—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Equal Access to Quality Education Act of 2013/s:2/ss:b

text.#text:
how
			 the eligible partnership will meet the purposes under

how
			 the partnership will carry out the activities required under subsection (d),
			 including—

how the
			 partnership will design, implement, or enhance a year-long and rigorous
			 teaching residency program component; and

how
			 the grant will increase the number of highly qualified teachers —

in high-need
			 schools operated by high-need local educational agencies (in urban or rural
			 school districts); and

in high-need
			 academic subjects; and

with
			 respect to the teacher induction and retention program that will be carried out
			 using the grant—

the partnership’s
			 capability and commitment to, and the accessibility to and involvement of
			 teachers in, the use of empirically based practice and scientifically valid
			 research on teaching and learning;

a description of
			 how the partnership will design and implement an induction program to support,
			 through not less than the first 2 years of teaching, all new teachers who are
			 prepared by the teacher preparation program in the partnership and who teach in
			 the high-need local educational agency in the partnership, and, to the extent
			 practicable, all new teachers who teach in such high-need local educational
			 agency, in the further development of the new teachers’ teaching skills,
			 including the use of mentors who are trained and compensated by such program
			 for the mentors’ work with new teachers.

An eligible partnership that receives a grant under this
			 section shall use the funds to carry out the following:

Establish or
			 support a teacher preparation program that—

requires
			 participants in the program to teach in a high-need school in such local
			 educational agency for at least 3 years after completing such residency;
			 and

awards a teaching credential, an
			 undergraduate degree, or a Masters degree that meets State requirements for a
			 teaching license or certification upon completion of the program.

Establish or
			 support a teacher induction and retention program that provides support and
			 advances the retention of beginning teachers and principals during not less
			 than the first 2 years of participation in such program, which promotes
			 effective teaching and leadership skills and includes—

high-quality
			 mentoring;

periodic,
			 structured time for collaboration and classroom observation opportunities with
			 teachers in the same department or field, including mentor teachers, as well as
			 time for information-sharing among teachers, principals, administrators, other
			 appropriate educators, and participating faculty in the partner institution of
			 higher education;

opportunities for
			 new teachers and principals to draw directly on the expertise of mentors,
			 faculty, local educational agency personnel, and researchers to support the
			 integration of empirically based practice and scientifically valid research
			 with practice;

the
			 development of skills in instructional and behavioral interventions derived
			 from empirically based practice, and where applicable, scientifically valid
			 research;

faculty
			 who—

model the
			 integration of research and practice in the classroom; and

assist new
			 teachers and principals with the effective use and integration of technology in
			 instruction.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Equal Access to Quality Education Act of 2013/s:2/ss:b

text.#text:
Otherwise fulfill
			 the purposes described in

, a
			 partnership that receives a grant under this section may use the funds for any
			 of the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Equal Access to Quality Education Act of 2013/s:2/ss:d/p:1

text.#text: In addition to the activities described in

Providing support
			 to each mentor teacher working with new teachers.

Providing
			 preparation in effective, evidence-based instructional assessment practices and
			 classroom management strategies for general education teachers serving students
			 with disabilities and students with limited English proficiency.

Enabling teachers to engage in study
			 groups, professional learning communities, and other collaborative activities
			 and collegial interactions regarding instruction assessment.

Paying for release
			 time and substitute teachers in order to enable teachers to participate in
			 professional development and mentoring activities.

Creating libraries of professional
			 material, catalogues of expert instruction, and education technology.

Providing
			 high-quality professional development for other instructional staff, such as
			 paraprofessionals, librarians, and counselors.

Developing
			 partnerships with businesses and community-based organizations.

Providing tuition
			 assistance, scholarships, or student loan repayment to teachers.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Equal Access to Quality Education Act of 2013/s:2/ss:d/p:1/sp:A

text.#text:
Providing stipends
			 or another financial incentive to participants in the teacher preparation
			 program under

Providing support for home visitation,
			 parenting education, and family engagement, especially for parents who have
			 limited English proficiency.

The Federal share of the cost of any activities funded by a
			 grant received under this section shall not exceed 75 percent.

The non-Federal share may be paid in cash or in
			 kind, fairly evaluated, including services.

In
			 this section:
The term

that may include a
			 teacher organization or a nonprofit educational organization.

term.#tail:
means a shared
			 responsibility of families and schools for student success, in which schools
			 and community-based organizations are committed to reaching out to engage
			 families, especially parents of non-Native English speakers, in meaningful ways
			 that encourage the families to actively support their children’s learning and
			 development, as well as the learning and development of other children. The
			 shared responsibility is continuous from birth through young adulthood and
			 reinforces learning that takes place in the home, school, and community.

text.#text: The term

that serves not fewer
			 than 10,000 low-income children;

for which not less than 20 percent
			 of the children served by the agency are low-income children;

that meets the eligibility

			 Program under

for which one or more

for which one or more schools
			 served by the agency has a high teacher turnover rate.

The term

is highly
			 qualified;

has a minimum of 3
			 years of teaching experience;

is recommended by
			 the principal and other current master and mentor teachers on the basis
			 of—

instructional excellence through
			 observations and other evidence of classroom practice, including
			 standards-based evaluations, such as certification by the National Board for
			 Professional Teaching Standards;

an ability, as demonstrated by evidence of
			 student learning in high-need schools, to increase student learning; and

excellent
			 instruction and communication with an understanding of how to facilitate growth
			 in other teachers, including new teachers; and

participates in
			 training and ongoing professional development on how to—

help
			 teachers learn to improve student achievement;

help teachers
			 learn to improve instruction; and

facilitate
			 mentor-to-mentor collaboration and coaching.

The
			 term

term.#tail:
means a program, based on
			 State or national professional teaching standards, that will measure teachers’
			 curriculum planning, instruction, and assessment of students, including
			 appropriate plans and adaptations for English language learners and students
			 with disabilities, and multiple sources of evidence about student learning.
			 Such assessment will be validated against professional assessment standards and
			 reliably scored by trained external evaluators with appropriate auditing of
			 scoring to ensure consistency.

text.#text:
The
			 term

term.#tail:
means a
			 program of instruction for individuals who have completed a baccalaureate
			 degree, that does not lead to a graduate degree, and that consists of courses
			 required by a State for a teacher candidate to receive a professional
			 certification or license that is required for employment as a teacher in an
			 elementary school or secondary school in that State.
